description: From Middle English respect, from Old French respect, also respit (“respect, regard, consideration”), from Latin respectus (“a looking at, regard, respect”), perfect passive participle of respiciō (“look at, look back upon, respect”), from re- (“back”) + speciō (“to see”). Doublet of respite.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) an attitude of consideration or high regard
(uncountable, always plural) Polite greetings, often offered as condolences after a death.
(countable) a particular aspect, feature or detail of something
(uncountable) an attitude of consideration or high regard
examples: Synonyms: deference, esteem, consideration, regard, fealty, reverence, aught
He is an intellectual giant, and I have great respect for him.
We do respect people for their dignity and worth.
Synonyms: admiration, esteem, reverence, regard, recognition, veneration, honor

entries.meaning: (uncountable, always plural) Polite greetings, often offered as condolences after a death.
examples: The mourners paid their last respects to the deceased poet.

entries.meaning: (countable) a particular aspect, feature or detail of something
examples: This year's model is superior to last year's in several respects.
Synonyms: aspect, dimension, face, facet, side

verbs.description: respect (third-person singular simple present respects, present participle respecting, simple past and past participle respected)

examples: She is an intellectual giant, and I respect her greatly.

entries.meaning: To have regard for something, to observe a custom, practice, rule or right.
examples: I respect your right to hold that belief, although I think it is nonsense.
I respect your right to feel offended, even though most people, myself included, totally disagree and don’t find the comment offensive in the slightest.
They failed to respect the treaty they had signed, and invaded.

entries.meaning: To take notice of; to regard as worthy of special consideration; to heed.
(transitive, dated except in "respecting") To relate to; to be concerned with.
examples: Whatever they are else, they are always chastisements; and correction respects faults.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To regard; to consider; to deem.
